content:
I've edited the statement based on the comment in the forum ( https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-self-driving-car-testing/2275/19 ). The following are the details of the main changes.

Goal
* Changed:
On an ASCII vertical scrolling, you display the car on each portion of the road.
to:
On an ASCII road, you display the car moving from the top to the bottom.

* Added:
For each step, the car moves down one line. At the same time, it shifts one column to the left for {{L}}, one column to the right for {{R}}, or stays in the same column for {{S}}.

Changed:
ahead, then three times to the right
to:
ahead (down), then three times down and right

Added:
If the car's position coincides with a road character, display only the car (#) in that position.

Input
* Changed:
Line 2: The position X (starting from 1) of the car at the beginning, then a list of command separated by a semi-colon ;
to:
Line 2: The column position (1-based index) of the car at the beginning, then a list of commands, all separated by a semi-colon ;

Constraints
* Added:
1 ≤ [[N]] ≤ 20
Output: 1 ≤ number of lines, length of each line ≤ 40

Cases
* Revised "Gentleman, start your engines" (Validator 2) to have one less line in both the input and the output because the validator was originally the same as Test 2.

Edited: I replaced the last command "4S" by "3S" in the third test and validator as the car commands were 1 command longer than the road, as mentioned in the forum https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/community-puzzle-self-driving-car-testing/2275
I also corrected a typo ("X" instead of "#" in the output description).
Thanks again JBM. It seems to be perfect now.

I've updated the statement and I/O to match the rest of the problems' typography.
The validators were inconsistent between semicolon-separated and semicolon-terminated, but since the format specified "separated" I dropped the trailing ones to make it all consistent.
That broke your code in cases where the last command isn't S. So I fixed that.
Your code also made the road one character shorter than in the input. I assumed that's a side effect of the ¤ to # transition, and fixed that too.

So all in all, it's good to go for me, I'm approving. But you might want to cross-check I didn't mess up your road widths too much.
Please don't require the use of non-ASCII characters when you can avoid it.

I've replaced the non ASCII char by a "#"

Thanks for your comment.
